Key dimensionality-reduction method; conceptually intuitive (rotate data to align with directions of greatest variance) but mathematically involved.
Philosophical concept used to model rational action in AI; not widely familiar but explainable with simple examples.

Mid-level AI concept: combines probabilistic modeling with general-purpose programming; requires understanding of probability and inference, but can be taught via examples in probabilistic programming languages (PPLs).
A rule-based AI architecture that is straightforward conceptually, though the term may be unfamiliar to non-specialists.
Common foundational term; easy to explain, though technical nuances exist (syntax, semantics, compilers).
A classic logic programming language central to AI and computational linguistics; conceptually approachable via facts/rules but requires some background in logic and declarative programming.
Foundational logical system for AI reasoning; explainable with truth tables and connectives; abstract but teachable; does not handle quantification like first-order logic.
A widely used but conceptually dense reinforcement learning algorithm; understandable at a high level but requires several RL concepts to fully grasp.
Python is a widely-known, beginner-friendly programming language commonly discussed in AI contexts.
A popular open-source ML library for building and training neural networks, widely used in academia and industry; easy to explain as a framework for AI models, with some depth in tensor operations.
Foundational reinforcement learning algorithm; approachable with a concrete example but may be conceptually challenging for general audiences.
A foundational AI/philosophy concept illustrating the challenge of exhaustively listing action preconditions; highlights why real-world reasoning resists simple, fully specified plans.

Fundamental logic term; can be taught with simple examples (universal and existential quantifiers). Might be abstract for non-logic/non-CS learners; use intuitive analogies (all vs some) to aid understanding.
A conceptually advanced topic that could influence AI; explainable in simple terms but real-world details rely on quantum physics and computer science.
A straightforward concept bridging databases and information retrieval; generally easy to explain to non-majors, with SQL being a common example.
A solid, concise description of R as a free software environment for statistics and graphics, useful in AI/data science contexts.
Specialized ML concept; moderately difficult for non-majors, but the gist is intuitive (basis functions plus linear output).
A foundational ensemble learning method that combines multiple decision trees to improve accuracy and reduce overfitting; widely taught and fairly approachable to explain.

A moderately approachable AI concept; relates to software that derives conclusions from knowledge using logical methods; easy to illustrate with simple examples but touches deeper ideas like deduction and induction.
A foundational neural network model for sequence data; introduces memory via feedback connections and is widely used for time-series, language, and other sequential tasks.
A foundational statistical technique in AI; generally approachable to explain, but its nuances (assumptions, regularization, and interpretation) require some math background.
A core ML technique to prevent overfitting; fairly approachable to explain with simple analogies (penalizing model complexity).
Foundational AI concept; approachable in broad terms but the formal framework and algorithms can be challenging for non-experts.

A practical approach to align AI behavior with human judgments by learning a reward model from human ratings and optimizing the policy accordingly; conceptually simple but technically and ethically nuanced.
Fundamental ML concept that describes learning useful data representations automatically; easy to convey at a high level but details vary by method.
Conceptually approachable and useful for certain time-series tasks, but the idea of fixed random reservoirs and high-dimensional projection can be counterintuitive and requires some background.
Foundational web data modeling standard; moderately abstract but explainable with examples of triples (subject-predicate-object) used in metadata and semantic web.
A concise, but fairly specialized concept; foundational for energy-based generative models, though less common in everyday practice than newer deep learning architectures.
A specialized rule-based inference technique; moderately difficult for non-specialists but explainable with diagrams and simple analogies.
Moderately specialized term; explainable with a simple example, but not common outside AI contexts.
Interdisciplinary field bridging hardware and software; generally recognizable, but underlying concepts involve multiple engineering and AI principles that can be technically deep.
A foundational AI concept describing systems that use explicit if-then rules rather than learned models; relatively easy to explain but less flexible than modern learning-based approaches.
A central logic concept in AI/CS: whether a Boolean formula can be made true under some interpretation, underpinning the SAT problem and related reasoning tasks.
A foundational concept; easy to explain as a method to locate information, but the idea of searching within abstract problem spaces adds depth for deeper study.
Core GA concept: selecting individuals for reproduction based on fitness, explainable with simple fitness-based examples.
A fairly accessible concept describing autonomous operation of computer systems; easy to explain, though real implementations can be technically involved.
A straightforward, foundational concept in AI for representing knowledge as concepts connected by relations; suitable for introductory coverage.
A core AI/semantic-web concept that demonstrates automated inference over ontologies; moderately technical but explainable with simple examples.

A mid-level concept: semantic queries use meaning and relationships to retrieve information, enabling both precise results and broader, exploratory questions. Explainable with examples like knowledge graphs or ontologies.
A formal, essential concept in CS and AI-related areas; understandable with math background, but not a common everyday term for non-CS audiences.
A clear, practical ML concept that is moderately easy to explain and widely used in scenarios with limited labeled data.
Moderately difficult domain-specific concept; can be taught with simple analogies using combining information from multiple sensors to reduce uncertainty.
A specialized formal method for reasoning about program memory and mutable state; moderately difficult for non-specialists, but powerful for program verification.
A practical subfield of machine learning focused on learning similarity metrics for tasks like ranking, retrieval, and verification; conceptually approachable but benefits from some ML background.
A widely taught optimization technique; intuitive cooling analogy helps explain probabilistic search for global optima, reasonable for non-majors.
Clear beginner-friendly intro to embodied AI concepts; contrasts bottom-up, sensorimotor focus with abstract reasoning, but glosses over deeper nuances.
A core but specialized logical framework for reasoning about actions and change; approachable with concrete examples but still technically dense.
A highly technical concept from logic programming; foundational in Prolog-style inference, but not commonly encountered outside specialized AI or CS courses.
Fundamental and widely understood; easily explained and directly relevant to AI systems.
A standard, practical field bridging engineering and software development; accessible with a basic CS background.
An interdisciplinary AI concept combining space and time reasoning; moderately familiar and easy to explain, with relevance to navigation, robotics, and planning.
A concise, accessible entry point: SPARQL is the standard query language for RDF data, akin to SQL for semantic web graphs; useful but niche outside AI/semantic web.
Moderately advanced ML concept involving representing data using a small number of learned basic elements; explainable with sparse coding analogies but requires linear algebra basics.
A common, easily explained AI term describing the process of converting spoken language into written text.
Moderately advanced; involves timing of spikes and dynamic states; less familiar than standard ANNs but explainable with simple neuron-fire analogies.
A basic CS concept describing a program's memory of past events; easy to explain with simple examples (stateful vs stateless).
A foundational concept in AI/ML, approachable via concrete examples (e.g., spam vs. non-spam) but may require some statistical grounding for deeper understanding.
A solid intro to on-policy reinforcement learning; useful for understanding how action-taking policies are improved from actually executed actions.
A moderately advanced concept combining probabilistic modeling with relational structures; central to some AI/ML approaches but not everyday knowledge.
A fundamental AI/optimization concept that is moderately challenging for non-experts; explainable with basic probability and optimization ideas.
A moderately technical probabilistic NLP term; not widely known among non-specialists, but explainable with a simple probabilistic language interpretation.
Classic symbolic AI planning model; foundational to modern planners, though the formalism is now superseded by more advanced approaches.
A clear, widely understood term for a domain expert; easy to explain and recognize in AI contexts.
A pivotal but speculative concept; explainable at a high level, though it invites nuance about definitions, timelines, and ethical implications.
A foundational ML concept that is reasonably approachable for non-majors, though formal details like generalization and inductive bias add depth.
A core ML method that’s powerful but mathematically involved; good to introduce after basics of linear separation and optimization.
Clear concept of emergent collective behavior; generally approachable, though detailed modeling can be mathematically complex.
A foundational AI paradigm based on rules and logic; easier to understand than deep learning, but less central in modern practice compared to subsymbolic approaches.

Not standard terminology; largely synonymous with AI but framed to emphasize non-natural, machine-generated intelligence; may confuse beginners; useful for philosophical or ontology discussions but not common in textbooks.
A specialized interdisciplinary term. Useful for linking AI with how brain networks process information, but may be unfamiliar to non-specialists.
A speculative, high-level concept that is widely debated; accessible in idea but nuanced in definitions and implications, suitable for interdisciplinary discussion.
A core reinforcement learning concept that is moderately challenging for beginners but explainable via a simple bootstrapped update (TD(0)) using observed reward and the next state's value.
A highly specialized interdisciplinary concept that merges tensor mathematics with neural computation; difficult for non-specialists but central to mathematical brain-function models.
Widely used ML library; essential for many AI workflows; easy to explain at a high level, though the implementation details of dataflow graphs can be advanced for beginners.
A fairly specialized but foundational subfield that links formal theory with AI; can be challenging for non-CS audiences.
A core theoretical concept that underpins AI algorithms and limits; approachable with analogies but remains abstract, requiring some mathematical background.

A Bayesian action-selection method for exploration-exploitation in multi-armed bandits; fairly explainable with intuition about sampling from posterior beliefs, but it requires probabilistic background.
A foundational algorithmic concept describing how runtime grows with input size; generally easy to grasp conceptually, though formal notation (Big-O) adds depth.
A practical ML technique that reuses knowledge from one task to improve performance on a related task, often by fine-tuning pretrained models or using learned features.
A foundational neural architecture in modern NLP that uses attention; approachable with a high-level explanation but requires study to implement and tune.
A challenging but increasingly relevant concept at the intersection of AI, biotechnology, and ethics.
Foundational concept in formal methods and AI planning; easy to explain at a high level (states and transitions), but the labeling details and formal frameworks can be abstract.
A fundamental CS concept that is approachable with simple examples (e.g., pre-order, in-order, post-order traversals) and commonly taught in AI/CS courses.
Key concept that generalizes SAT to alternating quantifiers and underpins PSPACE-completeness; difficult for non-specialists but essential for understanding complexity classes.
Foundational computation model; widely taught and cited in AI and CS theory; approachable via simple tape-head analogy but remains abstract.
A classic, intuitive benchmark for AI that is easy to explain, but its limitations (e.g., deception vs. true understanding) invite deeper discussion.

A foundational concept in programming languages that is reasonably approachable for newcomers; useful for understanding how AI systems reason about data and interfaces, with some nuances (static vs dynamic typing) that add depth.
Foundational ML concept describing learning patterns from unlabeled data; can be introduced with clustering and density estimation, though some advanced variants involve complex mathematics.
A specialized hardware term for AI vision acceleration; like a GPU for vision tasks, not widely familiar to non-experts.
Nonstandard/ambiguous term; parallels AI-complete problems; high-level concept but unclear without citation.
A historically significant AI QA system; moderately familiar and explainable at a high level, but details like DeepQA and NLP are more complex.

A foundational concept that contrasts narrow task-focused AI with broader, general AI; easy to illustrate with everyday examples (chatbots, spam filters) but may require context for the general vs. strong AI distinction.
A moderately accessible ML concept about training models with imperfect or indirect labels rather than fully annotated data.
A mid-level NLP concept that represents words as vectors in a real-valued space; intuitive to explain but with some math under the hood.
A high-performance gradient boosting library widely used in ML; understandable at a high level but the underlying math and implementation details are technical.
